H0.text: Dry line is the weather condition that contributes most to the formation of heavy smog in a city experiencing smog formed by motor vehicle exhaust.

H1.text: A cold front is the weather condition that contributes most to the formation of smog in a city experiencing heavy smog formed by motor vehicle exhaust.

H2.text: Tropical cyclone is the weather condition that contributes most to the formation of smog in a city experiencing heavy smog formed by motor vehicle exhaust.

H3.text: Temperature inversion is the weather condition that most contributes to the formation of smog caused by motor vehicle exhaust in a city experiencing heavy smog.

A4.text: During a severe inversion, trapped air pollutants form a brownish haze that can cause respiratory problems.

A5.text: Temperature inversions stop atmospheric convection (which is normally present) from happening in the affected area and can lead to high concentrations of atmospheric pollutants.
